required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of the Intubation Condition Between Two Different Types of Video Laryngoscope Blades
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of the Intubation Condition Between Using Two Types of Blade in Patients Receiving Tracheal Intubation Using Videolaryngoscope: Channeled Blade vs. Non-channeled Blade

lead_sponsor.agency: Kyung Hee University Hospital at Gangdong

clinical_study.source: Kyung Hee University Hospital at Gangdong

brief_summary.textblock: The present study compares two different types of videolaryngoscope blade, which is a channeled and non-channeled blade. The purpose of the study is to investigate the effect of the type of videolaryngoscope blade on the intubation condition.

detailed_description.textblock: In tracheal intubation for general anesthesia, one of the two types of the blade during a video laryngoscopy can be used, one is a channeled blade that has a channel for tracheal tube launching, the other is a non-channeled blade. In the present study, the outcomes by using two types of the videolaryngoscope blade such as the intubation condition, intubation time, first-pass rate, and the incidence of intubation-related complications were compared.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Patients requiring tracheal intubation for general anesthesia

secondary_outcome.description: the success rate of tracheal intubation with one attempt
the incidence of overall complications related with tracheal intubation

arm_group.description: Group of patients using a channeled blade for videolaryngoscopy
Group of patients using a non-channeled blade (standard type) for videolaryngoscopy

intervention.description: In the present group, a tracheal tube was launched in the channel of the blade before tracheal intubation
In the present group, a tracheal tube was not launched in the videolaryngoscope blade before tracheal intubation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients receiving tracheal intubation for general anesthesia
- Patients with physical status 1, 2, or 3 by American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Body mass index <18.5 kg/m2 or >35 kg/m2
- Patients with a history of airway surgery
- Patients with increased risk of aspiration
- Patients who have any pathology (polyp, tumor, or inflammation) in the upper airway and larynx

overall_official.affiliation: Kyung Hee University Hospital at Gangdong

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Kyung Hee University Hospital at Gangdong
